skill.description: Write Python code following FiftyOne's official conventions. Use when contributing to FiftyOne, developing plugins, or writing code that integrates with FiftyOne's codebase.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only prompt templates and code style guidelines. No executable code, network calls, file access, or system capabilities. Behavior matches stated purpose exactly.

content.value_statement: Writing code for FiftyOne requires specific conventions for imports, docstrings, and module structure. This skill ensures your contributions follow FiftyOne's official style guide for clean, consistent code.
actual_capabilities: Generate Python modules with FiftyOne's required copyright header and structure
Organize imports in the standard four-group format (stdlib, third-party, eta, fiftyone)
Write Google-style docstrings with Args, Returns, and Raises sections
Create private helper functions with underscore prefix naming
Implement lazy imports for heavy dependencies using fou.lazy_import()
Add proper error handling with logger.warning() for non-fatal errors
limitations: Does not execute or validate generated code
Does not access or modify local files
Does not install or check package dependencies
Limited to Python code generation for FiftyOne ecosystem

use_cases.title: Contribute to FiftyOne core
use_cases.description: Generate pull requests that pass FiftyOne's code review by following official conventions.

use_cases.title: Build FiftyOne plugins
use_cases.description: Create plugins that integrate seamlessly with FiftyOne's architecture and patterns.

use_cases.title: Maintain code consistency
use_cases.description: Ensure team codebases follow FiftyOne conventions for maintainability.

prompt_templates.title: Basic module structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Python module template for FiftyOne with the required copyright header, four-group imports, logger setup, and example public and private functions.

prompt_templates.title: Function with docstring
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Google-style docstring for a function that takes a dataset and returns filtered samples. Include Args, Returns, and Raises sections.

prompt_templates.title: Import organization
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to organize imports for a module that uses numpy, fiftyone.core.labels, fiftyone.core.utils, and eta.core.utils following FiftyOne conventions.

prompt_templates.title: Error handling pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate code that gracefully handles optional imports using hasattr() guards and logger.warning() for non-fatal errors.

output_examples.input: Generate a Python module for a FiftyOne operator that loads image metadata.
output: Module structure with copyright header and four import groups
Imports: stdlib (os, logging), third-party (numpy), eta (eta.core.utils), fiftyone (fiftyone.core.labels)
Google-style docstring with Args and Returns sections
Public function delegating to private helper with underscore prefix

best_practices: Always use the four-group import order and alphabetize within each group
Prefix private helper functions with underscore and keep them focused
Use standard FiftyOne aliases (fol, fou, fof, fom) for cleaner imports
Leverage fou.lazy_import() for heavy or optional dependencies
anti_patterns: Do not skip the copyright header docstring in module files
Do not mix import groups or alphabetize across groups
Do not use bare except: clauses without specifying exception type
Do not write redundant utilities when FiftyOne already provides them

faq.question: Which Python versions does this skill support?
faq.answer: The conventions follow FiftyOne's current Python version requirements. Check FiftyOne documentation for supported versions.

faq.question: What are the import group limits?
faq.answer: Four groups only: stdlib, third-party, eta packages, FiftyOne. Alphabetize within each group independently.

faq.question: Can I use this for non-FiftyOne code?
faq.answer: The skill focuses on FiftyOne conventions. General Python style should use other tools or guidelines.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only generates text templates. It never accesses files, networks, or executes code.

faq.question: Why are my imports failing validation?
faq.answer: Check import order, alphabetization within groups, and that you use standard aliases (fol, fou, fof).

faq.question: How does this compare to Black or pylint?
faq.answer: This skill enforces architectural and naming conventions. Use Black for formatting and pylint for linting alongside it.
